Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: GOALI: Adaptive and Flexible Spectrum Optical Networking

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study and develop technology for Elastic Optical Networks (EONs). In EONs flexible amounts of spectral bandwidth may be allocated to each data channel without requiring adherence to a fixed wavelength grid. Such an approach is well-suited for supporting a wide range of dynamic traffic demands in a bandwidth-efficient manner. Key enabling technologies, optical arbitrary waveform generation
(OAWG) and optical arbitrary waveform measurement (OAWM), will enable elastic optical networking over a large spectrum by dividing the spectrum into spectral slices and dynamically processing information at lower rates compatible with CMOS electronics. The project will leverage these technologies as a basis for innovative hardware and software solutions for EON technology, architectures, protocols, network control and management, system integration, and testbed integration.

Advances in the basic architecture and technology for optical networking is important for US competitiveness. The project will work with several US-based industrial organizations as a means of technology transfer. The research results and publications will likely to impact standardization activities of flexible grid networking (e.g. International Telecommunication Union ITU-T SG15 on flex grid). The project will link education and research and serve as a rich platform for crossdisciplinary education in optical and higher-layer networking, and in computer engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent advances in optical networking technology has led to the development of flexible spectrum optical transmission systems in which each optical channel is no longer confined to the traditional fixed channel spacing 50 GHz, but may occupy a flexible amount of spectral bandwidth depending on the line rate and modulation format of the signal. Such systems, referred to as flexible-grid optical networks or elastic optical networks (EONs), allow for a more efficient utilization of spectrum resources. Combining EON technology with a software-defined network (SDN) control paradigm will result in a highly dynamic and flexible optical layer that is capable of rapidly provisioning a wide range of flexible optical-layer services. In such a dynamic scenario, a key issue that arises is how to efficiently utilize optical resources while meeting the service requirements of requesting applications.

The most basic service in an EON is the provisioning of a simple optical circuit, or lightpath, between two end points. The basic provisioning problem in this instance is known as the routing, modulation format selection, and spectrum assignment (RMSA) problem. That is, for each connection request, one must find a route for the request over the optical network, determine the modulation format for the signal of the connection, and assign a set of spectrum slots on each link along the route of the connection. The problem is subject to the wavelength continuity and contiguity constraints, which state that, in the absence of regenerators or wavelength converters, the connection must occupy the same set of spectrum slots on each link of the connection, and the connection must be assigned a contiguous block of spectrum slots on each link. The problem is also subject to reachability constraints, which specify the maximum distance that an optical signal of a given line rate and modulation format may traverse until the signal needs to be regenerated. When connections arrive and depart from an EON over time, the spectrum may become fragmented, making it more difficult to find continuous and contiguous spectrum blocks. Furthermore, when resources are reserved in advance, fragmentation in the time domain may also emerge.

This project focused on the investigation and evaluation of methods for routing, modulation format selection, and spectrum assignment in elastic optical networks. In particular, the project considered approaches for addressing RMSA when connections are scheduled in advance and are used for applications such as bulk data transfers between data centers. Consideration of the holding time extends the RMSA problem to also include the problem of scheduling in the time domain. We developed several techniques for provisioning and scheduling spectrum resources while attempting to minimize the fragmentation of resources in the spectrum and time domains. Our techniques involve defining metrics to evaluate the degree of fragmentation on links, and also utilize scheduling over multiple paths in order to more efficiently utilize resources. Our techniques are shown to significantly reduce the blocking of connections while also improving the utilization of spectrum resources. 

Another aspect of the project focused on addressing RMSA for connections that can dynamically increase or decrease their allocated spectrum over time in response to changes in traffic. We consider an approach in which each connection is allocated a base amount of spectrum for operating at a base transmission rate, while some additional spectrum is shared by all channels to enable some of these channels to dynamically transition to a higher transmission rate (peak rate) by increasing their spectrum allocation. We develop several spectrum allocation techinques that provide a trade-off between the number of connections that can be allowed into the network at their base rate and the number of connections that can simultaneously operate at their peak rates.  

In terms of broader impact, many of the proposed techniques can be incorporated into emerging control planes for elastic optical networks,enabling network operators or service providers to provide a greater range of services in a spectrum-efficient manner. Furthermore,the project has provided valuable research training experience for a number of graduate students.
